within it will be dilated. After having thus,
often enough, alternately produced the ascent 
and descent of mercury, not any [no] perceptible 
trace of air will remain within the spectral tube.
8. A tube evacuated in this way does not 
permit the induction current of Ruhmkorff’s
smaller apparatus, which in air gives a spark 
of about 15mm, to pass through. The current of 
his large apparatus <u>enforces the <\u> forces a passage 
but the spectrum we obtain in this case is very 
faint. It shows no traces of the bands of nitrogen 
but solely the lines of hydrogen and the large 
fields of vaporised <s>coal<\s] carbon (51). The hydrogen 
lines take their origin from hygroscopic water 
covering the interior surface of the spectral tube 
the <u>coal<\u> [carbon] bands probably from the minute traces 
of fat[ty] matter hitherto employed in greasing 
the stopcocks. (The oxigen simultaneously 
obtained by decomposition is not indicated)
The hydrogen lines, given by spectral tubes 
made of com[m]on glass are more brilliant then 
those of tubes made of less fusible glass: the 
hygroscopic state of the glass not being the 
same in both cases. Though, within the interior 
of the Exhaustor, the air is in contact with 
the surface of concentrated English sulfuric 
acid, or, what is preferable, with anhydr<u>ic<\u> [ous]
phosphoric acid, we never succeeded in ex 
pelling the last traces of hydroscopic water,
not even <u>in<\u> [by] heating the spectral tube
